title: Sorted³ vs Things 3 for Minimalists
meta_description: Sorted³ vs Things 3 for minimalists who want clear task lists without automatic scheduling, time blocking pressure, or dynamic reshuffling.
constraint_lens: You want tasks listed clearly without automatic scheduling, time blocking pressure, or dynamic reshuffling.

verdict.summary: Things 3 wins for minimalists who want a clean list of what to do. It centers on projects and simple lists without automatically scheduling tasks into time blocks. Sorted³ actively encourages time mapping and auto scheduling of tasks into your day. If automatic scheduling becomes a distraction, Sorted³ fails first.
verdict.decision_rule: If automatic scheduling becomes a distraction, Sorted³ fails first.

sections.heading: Why this matters for Minimalists
sections.content: You said you want tasks listed clearly without time blocking pressure. As a minimalist, features that push you to assign time slots or constantly adjust your day can feel like noise. A stable list that stays readable is easier to live with.

bullets.point: Automatic scheduling that places tasks into available time slots
bullets.why_it_matters: Your day is mapped visually, but seeing tasks reshuffled adds movement that can distract from simple list clarity.

bullets.point: Time map view that blends calendar events and tasks together
bullets.why_it_matters: You get a full picture of your day, yet mixing tasks into calendar style blocks increases visual density.

bullets.point: Auto rearrange feature when priorities change
bullets.why_it_matters: Tasks shift dynamically, but constant updates can make the list feel unstable.

bullets.point: Clean Today list that shows tasks without forcing time slots
bullets.why_it_matters: You can see what to do without assigning each task a specific hour.

bullets.point: Simple project and area structure with optional headings
bullets.why_it_matters: You can organize lightly without activating scheduling systems.
Your lists stay stable unless you manually reorder them.

sections.heading: Where each tool can break down

items.fails_when: You feel pressured to assign time blocks or react to auto rearranged tasks.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Things 3 if you prefer a steady list without dynamic scheduling.

items.fails_when: You want your tasks automatically mapped into open time in your day.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Sorted³ if structured time mapping helps you stay on track.

sections.heading: When this verdict might flip
sections.content: If you start missing deadlines because you never assign time to tasks, Sorted³ may become helpful by forcing tasks into visible time slots.

sections.heading: Quick decision rules
rules: If you want a stable list with no time pressure, choose Things 3.
If automatic scheduling feels distracting, avoid Sorted³.
If you need tasks mapped directly into your calendar, Sorted³ may fit better.

faqs.a: It strongly encourages mapping tasks into time slots through its scheduling view.
Yes, it focuses on clean lists and light structure without automatic scheduling.

faqs.q: Which tool keeps tasks more stable?
faqs.a: Things 3 keeps tasks stable because it does not auto rearrange them.

faqs.q: Can I ignore scheduling features in Sorted³?
faqs.a: You can, but the app is centered around its time mapping system, which remains prominent.
